intro: Crataegus texana var. dasyphylla, commonly known as the Texas hawthorn, is a shrub or small tree native to the southern United States. It typically grows to a height of 3–10 meters and is characterized by its thorny branches and clusters of white to pinkish flowers. The plant produces small, red berries that are an important food source for birds and other wildlife. It thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, sandy soils and full sun. The leaves are usually oval to elliptic in shape, with serrated margins and a leathery texture.
